column1: Rule 1: Modifiers containing both an amino group (-NH2) and a carboxylic acid group (-COOH) in a linear, unhindered arrangement, without adjacent bulky substituents, tend to result in a high yield.
column2: Rule 2: Modifiers with a phenyl group attached to a carboxylic acid group (-C6H4-COOH) and additional electron-withdrawing groups (such as -NO2) tend to result in a high yield.
column3: Rule 3: Modifiers containing multiple hydroxyl groups (-OH) tend to result in a high yield, especially when these groups are part of a sugar-like structure.
column4: Rule 4: Modifiers with a pyridine ring tend to result in a high yield when the pyridine is not substituted with electron-withdrawing groups.
column5: Rule 8: Modifiers with a benzofuranone structure tend to result in a high yield.
column6: Rule 11: Modifiers with a sulfanyl group (-SH) attached to a short aliphatic chain tend to result in a high yield.
column7: Rule 12: Modifiers with a phenyl ring with multiple methoxy groups (-OCH3) tend to result in a low yield.
column8: Rule 13: Modifiers with a carboxylic acid group attached to a pyridine ring tend to result in a high yield.
column9: Rule 15: Modifiers with an indole group tend to result in a high yield.
